answer:
<analysis/>
From the pavement markings and the large, three‐arrow overhead diagram visible in frames 4–5, the ego vehicle is in the lane whose marking (and sign depiction) shows both a left‐turn arrow and a through arrow.  In other words, that lane legally allows either proceeding straight through the intersection or making a left turn.  One clue is the “RIGHT LANE MUST TURN RIGHT” sign off to the right (frames 1–2), which applies only to the far‐right lane.  Meanwhile, the lane the ego occupies (the next one to the left of the forced‐right lane) has the combined “left + straight” markings on the pavement (visible faintly in frames 4–5) and on the overhead sign.  Hence the correct choice is “Straight or Left.”
<analysis/>  

<answer>B</answer>  

Frame‐by‐frame reasoning:

1. Frames 1–2:  
   • A sign on the right says “RIGHT LANE MUST TURN RIGHT,” indicating the **far‐right** lane is for right turns only.  
   • The ego is clearly to the left of that forced‐right lane.

2. Frames 3–4:  
   • Traffic moves into position at the red light.  
   • The ego’s lane is neither the far‐left lane (which appears to be for highway/ramp travel or dedicated lefts) nor the far‐right forced‐right lane.  
   • The middle lanes’ pavement arrows are beginning to come into view.

3. Frame 5:  
   • The large overhead diagram sign shows three sets of arrows; the rightmost set in that sign depicts a through arrow and a right‐turn arrow (matching the forced‐right lane at the extreme right).  
   • The center‐lane portion of that sign (the lane ego is in) has a left‐turn arrow and a through arrow.  
   • Pavement markings under the black pickup also show a combined left + straight arrow.

Conclusion:  
Because the ego’s lane is the one marked for both straight and left turns, the single best choice from the list—Left only, Straight or Left, Straight only, Right only—is  
B. Straight or Left.
